facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1991 of 1971 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1991 of 1971. From the Judgment and, Order dated the 29th March, 1971, of the Bombay High Court and Bombay in Appeal No. 87 of 1970. M. Tarkunde and Rameshwar Nath for the appellant K.S. Ramamurthy and B.R. Agarwal for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAY, C. J.-This is an appeal by certificate from the judgment dated 29th March, 1971 of the High Court of Bombay.

facts.text: Appeal from Bombay High Court Judgment and Order dated 29th March 1971 in Appeal No. 87 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: From the Judgment and, Order dated the 29th March, 1971, of the Bombay High Court and Bombay in Appeal No. 87 of 1970. M. Tarkunde and Rameshwar Nath for the appellant K.S. Ramamurthy and B.R. Agarwal for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAY, C. J.-This is an appeal by certificate from the judgment dated 29th March, 1971 of the High Court of Bombay. The appellant filed this suit on 2 September, 1964 in the High Court of Bombay and claimed six months salary in lieu of numberice and gratuity for 16 years of service.

facts.text: Appellant filed suit on 2 September 1964 in Bombay High Court claiming six months salary in lieu of notice and gratuity for 16 years of service.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed this suit on 2 September, 1964 in the High Court of Bombay and claimed six months salary in lieu of numberice and gratuity for 16 years of service. In the year 1965 the appellant asked for discovery by the respondent of documents relating to pension scheme for foreign employees. The application for discovery was dismissed in the month of November, 1965.

facts.text: In 1965 appellant applied for discovery of documents relating to pension scheme for foreign employees.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1965 the appellant asked for discovery by the respondent of documents relating to pension scheme for foreign employees. The application for discovery was dismissed in the month of November, 1965. On 16 December, 1969 the appellant took out a Chamber Summons for amendment of the plaint.

facts.text: Application for discovery dismissed in November 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The application for discovery was dismissed in the month of November, 1965. On 16 December, 1969 the appellant took out a Chamber Summons for amendment of the plaint. The proposed amendments were twofold.

facts.text: On 16 December 1969 appellant took out Chamber Summons for amendment of plaint.

anchor.surface_text: On 16 December, 1969 the appellant took out a Chamber Summons for amendment of the plaint. The proposed amendments were twofold. The first set of amendment related to averments in support of the claim for gratuity which had already been alleged in the plaint.

facts.text: First set of proposed amendments related to claim for gratuity already alleged in plaint.

anchor.surface_text: The first set of amendment related to averments in support of the claim for gratuity which had already been alleged in the plaint. The second set of amendment related to averments in support of a claim for Rs. 850 per month by way of pension as and from 1 February, 1964 during the life time of the appellant.

facts.text: Second set of proposed amendments for claim of Rs. 850 per month pension from 1 February 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The second set of amendment related to averments in support of a claim for Rs. 850 per month by way of pension as and from 1 February, 1964 during the life time of the appellant. By an order dated 19 January, 1970 the appellant was allowed to amend the plaint in respect of the claim for gratuity.

facts.text: Order dated 19 January 1970 allowed amendment for gratuity claim.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated 19 January, 1970 the appellant was allowed to amend the plaint in respect of the claim for gratuity. The appellants proposed amendment in support of the claim for pension was refused.

facts.text: Proposed amendment for pension claim refused on 19 January 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants proposed amendment in support of the claim for pension was refused. By summons dated 27 April, 1970 the appellant sought an amendment of. the plaint claiming Rs. 68,000 as damages in relation to his right to pension.

facts.text: On 27 April 1970 summons for amendment claiming Rs. 68,000 damages for pension right.

anchor.surface_text: By summons dated 27 April, 1970 the appellant sought an amendment of. the plaint claiming Rs. 68,000 as damages in relation to his right to pension. By an order dated 6 July, 1970 the appellant was allowed to amend the plaint as prayed for.

facts.text: Order dated 6 July 1970 allowed amendment for Rs. 68,000 damages claim.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated 6 July, 1970 the appellant was allowed to amend the plaint as prayed for. The respondent preferred an appeal against the order dated 6 July, 1970. The High Court by judgment dated 29 March, 1971 allowed the appeal and set aside the order dated 6 July, 1970 allowing the amendment.

facts.text: Respondent preferred appeal against 6 July 1970 order.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent preferred an appeal against the order dated 6 July, 1970. The High Court by judgment dated 29 March, 1971 allowed the appeal and set aside the order dated 6 July, 1970 allowing the amendment. The appellant repeated the companytentions which had been advanced before the High Court.

facts.text: Bombay High Court by judgment dated 29 March 1971 allowed respondent's appeal and set aside 6 July 1970 order.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by judgment dated 29 March, 1971 allowed the appeal and set aside the order dated 6 July, 1970 allowing the amendment. The appellant repeated the companytentions which had been advanced before the High Court. First, it was said that numberappeal companyld lie against an order of amendment because it was number a judgment within the meaning of clause 15 of the Letters Patent.

facts.text: Appellant had 16 years of service.

anchor.surface_text: and claimed six months salary in lieu of numberice and gratuity for 16 years of service. In the year 1965 the appellant asked for discovery by the respondent of documents relating to pension scheme for foreign employees.

facts.text: Respondent contended that amendment claim was barred by limitation in 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent companytended before the trial Court entertaining the application for amendment of the plaint that the amendment should number be allowed inter alia on the ground that the alleged claim was barred by limitation in 1970.

facts.text: Second amendment application in 1970 related to damages for pension claim.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant made an application in December, 1969 for amendment of the plaint to claim pension. Those amendments were disallowed by the learned Chamber Judge. Four months thereafter the appellant sought to amend the plaint by adding certain paragraphs and those amendments were in relation to the appellants alleged claim for pension.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by certificate from Bombay High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAY, C. J.-This is an appeal by certificate from the judgment dated 29th March, 1971 of the High Court of Bombay. The appellant filed this suit on 2 September, 1964 in the High Court of Bombay and claimed six months salary in lieu of numberice and gratuity for 16 years of service.

facts.text: High Court found no special circumstances for amendment despite lapse of time.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly found that there were numberspecial circumstances to entitle the appellant to introduce by amendments such claim. For these reasons, the judgment of the High Court is upheld. The appeal is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal upholding High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly found that there were numberspecial circumstances to entitle the appellant to introduce by amendments such claim. For these reasons, the judgment of the High Court is upheld. The appeal is dismissed with companyts.

arguments.claim: Order for transfer of suit is not a judgment under clause 15 Letters Patent (citing Asrumati Debi)

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Asrumati Debi v. Kumar Rupendra Deb Raikot Ors. 1953 S.C.R. 1159 dealt with the question as to whether an order of transfer of a suit filed in the Jalpaiguri Court to the High Court to be tried in its Extraordinary Original Civil Jurisdiction was a judgment within the meaning of clause 15 of the Letters Patent.

arguments.claim: Judgment under clause 15 Letters Patent must satisfy two tests: final pronouncement ending proceeding and determination of right/liability

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Asrumati Debi's case supra said that a judgment within the meaning of clause 15 of the Letters Patent would have to satisfy two tests. First, the judgment must be the final pronouncement which puts an end to the proceeding so far as the court dealing with it is concerned.

arguments.claim: Test for judgment is its effect on the suit, not form (citing Tuljaram v. Alagappa)

anchor.surface_text: The test formulated by the Madras decision is not the form of the adjudication but its effect on the suit or proceeding in which it is made. The Madras High Court said if the effect is to put an end to the suit or proceeding so far as the Court before which the suit or proceeding is pending is concerned...

arguments.claim: Amendment order substituting new party taking away limitation defence is a judgment under clause 15 (citing M.B. Sarkar v. Powell)

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in the present case relied on the decision of the High Court at Calcutta in M.B. Sarkar Sons v. Powell Co. A.I.R. 1956 Cal. 630. In that case an amendment was allowed on Chambers Summons substituting in place of the original defendant...

arguments.claim: Limitation bar creates immunity from liability, a vested right that amendment cannot take away without special circumstances

anchor.surface_text: The right to claim that an introduction of a cause of action by amendment is barred by limitation is founded on immunity from a liability. A right is an averment of entitlement arising out of legal rules. A legal right may be defined as an advantage or benefit conferred upon a person by a rule of law.

arguments.claim: Amendment allowing time-barred claim takes away defendant's immunity and determines liability, hence is a judgment under clause 15

anchor.surface_text: Where, on the other hand, an amendment takes away from the defendant the defence of immunity from any liability by reason of limitation, it is a judgment within the meaning of clause 15 of the Letters Patent. The reason why it becomes a judgment is that it is a decision affecting the merits...

Four months thereafter the appellant sought to amend the plaint by adding certain paragraphs and those amendments were in relation to the appellants alleged claim for pension.

arguments.claim: Appellate court can interfere with discretionary amendment order if insupportable in law or unjust

anchor.surface_text: It was said on behalf of the appellant that if the learned Judge allowed the application the appellate court should not have interfered with the discretionary order. The amendment order is not purely of discretion. Even with regard to discretionary orders the appellate court can interfere where the order is insupportable in law or is unjust.

arguments.claim: No special circumstances to allow amendment taking away limitation defence (citing Charan Das v. Amir Khan)

anchor.surface_text: In exceptional cases an amendment has been allowed where the effect is to take away from a defendant a legal right which has accrued to him by lapse of time, because the court found that consideration of lapse of time is outweighed by the special circumstances of the case. See Charan Das v. Amir Khan 47 I.A. 255.

arguments.claim: There were no special circumstances to entitle amendment of time-barred claim

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly found that there were no special circumstances to entitle the appellant to introduce by amendments such claim. For these reasons, the judgment of the High Court is upheld.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: I.A. 255 . The High Court rightly found that there were numberspecial circumstances to entitle the appellant to introduce by amendments such claim. F

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court upholds High Court finding

holdings.text: An order allowing amendment of plaint that takes away the defendant's defence of limitation (immunity from liability) is a judgment within the meaning of clause 15 of the Letters Patent.

anchor.surface_text: Where, on the other hand, an amendment takes away from the defendant the defence of immunity from any liability by reason of limitation, it is a judgment within the meaning of clause 15 of the Letters Patent. The reason why it becomes a judgment is that it is a decision affecting the merits of the question between the parties by determining the right or liability based on limitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies two-fold test (finality and determination of right/liability) from Asrumati Debi; limitation bar creates vested immunity akin to right; cites effect test from Tuljaram and analogy from M.B. Sarkar.

holdings.text: An appellate court can interfere with a trial court's discretionary order allowing amendment if the order is insupportable in law or unjust.

anchor.surface_text: It was said on behalf of the appellant that if the learned Judge allowed the application the appellate court should not have interfered with the discretionary order. The amendment order is not purely of discretion. Even with regard to discretionary orders the appellate court can interfere where the order is insupportable in law or is unjust.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretionary orders are not immune from review; interference warranted when order deprives vested limitation right without justification.

holdings.text: There were no special circumstances outweighing the defendant's accrued right by lapse of time (limitation) to allow the amendment introducing the time-barred pension/damages claim.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly found that there were no special circumstances to entitle the appellant to introduce by amendments such claim. For these reasons, the judgment of the High Court is upheld. The appeal is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exceptional cases require special circumstances to override limitation right (citing Charan Das v. Amir Khan); none found here after review of facts; second amendment treated as new barred claim.

holdings.text: The right against introduction of time-barred cause of action by amendment is a vested legal right founded on immunity from liability.

anchor.surface_text: The right to claim that an introduction of a cause of action by amendment is barred by limitation is founded on immunity from a liability. A right is an averment of entitlement arising out of legal rules. A legal right may be defined as an advantage or benefit conferred upon a person by a rule of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defines legal right and immunity; limitation accrues as absence of power to sue and non-liability; amendment overriding it determines liability.

holdings.text: Views of Calcutta and Madras High Courts on 'judgment' under clause 15 Letters Patent preferred over Rangoon and Nagpur High Courts.

anchor.surface_text: The views of the High Courts at Calcutta and Madras with regard to the meaning of judgment are with respect preferred to the meaning of judgment given by the Rangoon and Nagpur High Courts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Calcutta/Madras emphasize effect on merits/right/liability; aligns with Supreme Court precedents like Asrumati Debi.

anchor.surface_text: Where, on the other hand, an amendment takes away from the defendant the defence of immunity from any liability by reason of limitation, it is a judgment within the meaning of clause 15 of the Letters Patent. The reason why it becomes a judgment is that it is a decision affecting the merits of the question between the parties by determining the right or liability based on limitation.
For these reasons, the judgment of the High Court is upheld. The appeal is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: It was said on behalf of the appellant that if the learned Judge allowed the application the appellate court should not have interfered with the discretionary order. The amendment order is not purely of discretion. Even with regard to discretionary orders the appellate court can interfere where the order is insupportable in law or is unjust.
For these reasons, the judgment of the High Court is upheld. The appeal is dismissed with costs.
